audio_caption: The clip begins with an enthusiastic male speaker introducing the idea that a large meal may make one feel big, but not nearly as large as the biggest objects in the universe, posing the question of what those are. Upbeat, rhythmic music plays with synth sounds.

The audio clip begins with a light and upbeat musical interlude, leading into a male voice introducing the content of a collaborative video about the largest and smallest objects in the universe. The speaker encourages viewers to engage with both videos and the comment section. The intro music then resumes, more pronounced, marking the transition to the main content. Following this is a brief explosive sound effect. A male voice proceeds with a slightly sarcastic tone, mentioning human-made structures, and the hope that Fast & Furious movies wonâ€™t suck, transitioning to a more serious tone as he contrasts these feats with the power of the natural world.

The audio clip begins with a male speaker describing impressive human constructions, such as the Burj Khalifa and Boeing's Everett factory, and comparing their size to natural landmarks, such as the Grand Canyon and the Chicxulub asteroid crater. His tone is factual and informative. He then asks, "But why limit ourselves to the only rock we've called home?"

The audio starts with a curious and excited-sounding male voice describing interesting geographical features in our solar system. He explains how the largest mountain in our solar system, Olympus Mons, is 16 miles above the surface of Mars and covers an area nearly the size of France. He then transitions to ask the listener what they would consider to be the largest object in our solar system, teasing the answer. This is briefly interrupted by a quick, playful, wind-like audio sound effect, and the speaker continues on to explain how the largest object isn't the Sun itself, but something that comes from it: coronal mass ejections.

The clip begins with a man excitedly describing a coronal ejection caused by a solar storm in 1859. He details the auroras that danced across the night sky, extending as far south as Mexico, and the ensuing telegraph failures. The man transitions to discussing potential damage from a similar solar storm hitting the planet today, followed by a shift to discussing beyond our solar system. The clip is backed by calm, unobtrusive music that seems to be electronic in nature.

The clip starts with a male speaker excitedly discussing Sagittarius A, a supermassive black hole at the center of our galaxy, comparing it in size to our sun. As he continues speaking, a musical underscore begins, adding a subtle, anticipatory tone to the discussion, and mentions another black hole, even larger, at the center of the M87 galaxy. He refers to it as "the chad of all black holes," describing its immense size and its photograph from last year. The music swells, enhancing the sense of wonder and scientific curiosity.

The audio clip begins with a male speaker introducing the "biggest of the big," referring to the "Hercules-Corona Borealis Great Wall." He speaks in an informative, slightly enthusiastic tone. The speaker notes that this "great GRB wall" contains billions of galaxies. He poses the question, "Why does it count as one big thing?" and elaborates on the idea of adding galaxies to create even bigger objects. There is no music or notable background sounds.

The clip features one male speaker describing the unique qualities of a gamma-ray burst, mentioning that it is separated spatially from its surroundings. He continues, explaining that gamma-rays are the most powerful type of radiation and emitted in a handful of stellar events such as supernovas or neutron star collisions. The speaker has a measured and educational tone.

The audio clip begins with a male speaker, speaking with a slightly excited and curious tone, referencing a "structure" that is "even so large", questioning how it fits into the evolution of the universe. He quotes Istvan Horvath, who discovered the "great GRB Wall", as being unable to explain how the structure could have formed in such a short time. A different male speaker, speaking in an explanatory and calm tone, then poses the question of why the "great GRB Wall" does not seem to fit our theories, and introduces the topic as involving the "cosmological principle". A very subtle and low electronic melody plays quietly in the background throughout the entire duration.

The audio begins with a calm and informative male voice explaining the cosmological principle and how it should appear consistent regardless of location or direction. He acknowledges that this may seem untrue due to the varying stars, planets, and galaxies we observe. He mentions that it's expected to be true above a very large length scale, because the universe was very small right after the Big Bang. He further explains that during this time, quantum fluctuations created non-uniformities, which were stretched into galaxies and clusters during a period of inflation. The voice becomes slightly more inquisitive while discussing how the Great GRB Wall contradicts the cosmological principle, but then states that the idea is not the end of the story. The voice continues by noting the likelihood of quantum fluctuations, and explains how the Great GRB Wall remains an open question in terms of the principle and theories of inflation. The voice concludes with, "For now, the largest structure in the universe may just be its greatest mystery." Finally, the sound transitions to a short musical stinger that emphasizes suspense.

The audio clip begins with a male speaker summarizing that the video was a collaboration with Zap Physics, describing the channel as a great channel focused on physics, and encouraging the listener to check out the collaborative video about the smallest object in the universe. The speaker ends the clip with a send-off stating, "Have a great day, and remember, there's always more to learn." Following this, a brief musical transition takes place, signaling the end of the clip. The speaker's tone throughout the speech is enthusiastic and encouraging.
